Opinion

Out with the Old School

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Distinctio, officia? Non nobis ea nisi voluptates beatae hic maiores sunt. Quibusdam.

February 2021 Issue

Image source: https://www.nbcnews.com/

By Birk Kensén

Feb. 7, 2021 Updated 10:06 a.m. CET

Today we’re pushing elementary students (first - ninth grade) to do up to eight hours of school and then pile them with homework for an additional one to three hours at home. No wonder that children today suffer from anxiety, depression, and sleep deprivation? With the long hours at school and home, many students lose their study motivation and/or have to give up hobbies such as sports and music. Imagine doing a full day at the office only to do another four or so hours of office work at home, Monday through Friday, and most of the weekends. How long would you hold?

This problem could be resolved by removing homework for children in elementary school and have teacher-led study groups for everyone who needs it. It’s an implementation that would benefit the teachers as well as the students. Having to correct and follow up on every single student takes a massive amount of time, it would eliminate a lot of overtime. An elementary teacher works on average 45 hours a week if not including breaks. Eight out of ten do an additional one to five hours on the weekend with pre-and post-work. By removing homework the teachers would be able to focus their time and energy on planning effective curriculums and meaningful lessons. Homework also creates a learning gap between children. The variation of different parents' ability to help their children with their assignments is vast. The parents’ access to time, energy, money, and education is a question of equality that directly affects students and their study results.

It is said that Einstein came up with the relativity theory while biking and that Charles Darwin came up with most of the science of evolution while taking long walks. By removing time-consuming home studies, children would have access to more free time to perform creativity-boosting activities such as sports. It’s been proven that creativity comes to us when we’re physically active. Studies show that students performed sixty percent better during brainstorming, and remembered on average twenty percent more at vocable tests after taking walks around campus beforehand.

Therefore, removing homework will benefit students immensely and improve their results as well as their creativity. Inequality between families who can and cannot help their children at home will no longer be an issue. Having more free time to participate in sports and activities will lead to reduced stress and anxiety, boosting creativity and improving general well-being. Benefitting not only students but teachers as well. By having more study free time, I believe it will increase students’ curiosity during class. Education will therefore have a feeling of purpose and meaning, instead of a necessary evil. By removing the old school, kids will no longer be too cool for school.
